FRS_Method: GPS CARRIER PHASE KINEMATIC RELATIVE POSITION

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Management and employees of GRAINCO FS, Inc. are committed to the prevention of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the Coal City Fire Department, Grundy County Emergency Planning Agency or other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.



      The primary activity at the facility is the storage of fertilizers for sale to farmers.  Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored, and distributed for direct application as a crop production nutrient.  The storage and handling system consists of a storage tank, loading risers, associated plumbing and nurse tanks. Access to the site is restricted to authorized facility employees, authorized management personnel and authorized contractors. 



      The facility has developed a worst case and alternative case scenario, however, since this is security-sensitive information it has been withheld from this Executive Summary as required by EPA regulations.



      This facility complies with EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule and with all applicable state codes and regulations. This facility has implemented the provisions of the Compressed Gas Association's (CGA's) "American National Standard Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia" (6th edition), commonly referred to as "ANSI/CGA G-2.1 2014", as adopted by state regulation and the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 20 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia". Compliance with these regulations and on-going training of our employees make up our accidental release prevention program.



      There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia for the covered process in the past five years that have caused any deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site; nor to our knowledge, have any accidental releases resulted in o

ffsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage or environmental damage.



     This facility is a non-responding facility. The facility has a written emergency action plan in accordance with OSHA standard 29 CFR 1910.38 and provide state and local authorities the emergency planning and community right-to-know infromation as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA).  In the event of an emergency involving anhydrous ammonia, it is our policy to notify the Coal City Fire Department and Grundy County EMA and request that they respond to our emergency. Our emergency action plans have been coordinated with both the fire department and EMA. 



     Safety improvements is an on-going process at the facility.  Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safe practices and operations.  In 2020, we plan to do maintenance and upgrade the facility to meet new state regulations for the handling and storage of anhydrous ammonia.
